stream_context.summary: Kaze reviews beta-test feedback and applies polish to Course 2 (especially underwater readability and escape routes), does ROM-size cleanup by deleting unused vanilla Mario 64 assets, and investigates long load times (including emulator differences) with a potential faster decompression algorithm from EggLab. He also outlines near-term world/overworld tasks (post-Bowser world-state changes, level entrances, Dory/Yoshi interaction) and hits a concerning crash when opening the Cloud Cap stage, then ends early due to a family birthday party as Zeina returns home.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete production progress (Course 2 nearing completion), technical gains (recovering ~0.5MB ROM space, planned faster decompression to cut load times), and reveals the next batch of narrative/overworld tasks plus an unresolved crash that could impact the schedule.

findings.summary: Kaze recovered almost half a megabyte of ROM space by deleting unused original Super Mario 64 assets that were still present in the ROM, improving headroom for RTYI content.
findings.quote: So I found almost half a megabyte of ROM space today... by deleting all the unused Mario 64 assets that were left in the ROM.

findings.summary: EggLab informed Kaze about an alternative decompression algorithm that is about twice as fast as the current standard; Kaze expects it could reduce ~3-second level loads to roughly half that time.
findings.quote: EggLab actually notified me about a decompression algorithm... about twice as fast as the standard one.

findings.summary: Kaze observes a mismatch in loading behavior between emulators (Project64 vs a more accurate/alternate setup), and suspects some of his graphics-render optimizations may have inadvertently slowed loading, complicating performance diagnosis.
findings.quote: I think some of my graph render optimizations also kind of slowed down loading time, which makes sense.

findings.summary: Course 2 has undergone extensive beta testing and is close to final; changes focus on reducing frustration and improving player guidance and navigation, particularly in underwater sections (thicker planks, coin icons on walls as visual hints, more platforms/escape points, slowed/thickened geometry).
findings.quote: Course 2 is almost perfect now... The main changes were in the underwater area... a lot of it is just easier.

findings.summary: Kaze confirms the project uses some assembly (ASM) alongside decomp-based C changes, implying low-level patches are still necessary for specific behaviors/performance.
findings.quote: Yeah, there's a little bit of assembly coding in this.

findings.summary: He implements/adjusts level exit “warp points” and proposes a more cinematic exit: leaving a level from a very high altitude so the transition visually sells vertical scale and progression.
findings.quote: Wouldn't it be fucking cool if after this level you exited from like really high up?

findings.summary: A level editor/workflow issue occurs: opening the Cloud Cap stage causes a crash; Kaze notes Git backups exist but treats the crash as a serious pipeline problem he wants to understand rather than just reverting.
findings.quote: Did it fucking crash when I opened the cloud cap... That's concerning.

findings.summary: Kaze blocks out a comedic NPC vignette: the Goomba King has quit ruling minions and is now fishing, including planned dialogue implying a change in identity/status; he iterates on modeling a fishing rod prop to sell the bit.
findings.quote: It's fishing here with the Goomba King. He's done with his minions and just decides to go fishing.

findings.summary: He transitions into a concrete “Part 2” task list for the next development chunk: fixing a sign, making the Bowser mech appear destroyed/smoking outside Bowser’s Burst after beating the first Bowser level, adding/finishing level entrances, and beginning minecart work; he also notes an overworld change involving Dory chained to a wall and a Yoshi-as-Dory NPC prompt.
findings.quote: Let's make a little to-do list here... start on minecart.

findings.summary: Kaze references paying Biobak in the future and ties it to an audio pipeline/tooling note (he mentions setting something up “with Wwise”), implying ongoing setup for compensation and/or production infrastructure as the project matures.
findings.quote: Once I can finally pay you... we really should be setting that up with Wwise.

biobak.summary: Biobak checks in during stream; Kaze responds that Course 2 is nearly finished and mentions he still has one beta-test video to review before finalizing remaining issues.
Biobak’s birthday comes up on stream; Kaze acknowledges it and jokes about eventually paying him enough to upgrade his computer, highlighting the informal but supportive collaboration tone.

zeina.summary: Zeina returns home near the end of stream; Kaze ends early to attend a child’s birthday party, briefly showing how family life constrains and shapes stream cadence and production blocks.

findings.summary: EggLab provides Kaze with information about a decompression algorithm reportedly ~2x faster than the current one, positioned as a direct fix for unacceptable load times.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If I was making a Zelda romhack, I would just make a Zelda game in my engine. It would genuinely be easier than dealing with the actual Zelda engine.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze articulates a core motivation behind his custom tech: decomp-based hacking evolves into building a reusable engine that can outgrow the constraints of the original N64 codebases.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: The first job is programming at Gears for Breakfast, the second job is making YouTube videos, and the third job is making our RTYI, I guess.
memorable_quotes.context: A candid snapshot of workload stacking—useful for interviews about sustainability, pacing, and why development choices prioritize efficiency (tooling, engine rewrites, load-time work).

key_stories.title: Recovering ROM space by deleting leftover vanilla assets
key_stories.summary: Kaze reports finding nearly half a megabyte of ROM space by removing unused original Mario 64 assets still sitting in the build. This creates practical headroom for new content and reduces the risk of late-stage memory/space crises.
key_stories.challenge: RTYI’s expanding custom content competes with the original game’s leftover data, risking ROM space pressure.
key_stories.process: He audits the base ROM contents and deletes unused vanilla assets that are no longer needed in RTYI.
key_stories.outcome: He recovers ~0.5MB of ROM space and feels materially safer about future additions.
key_stories.key_quote: I found almost half a megabyte of ROM space today... by deleting all the unused Mario 64 assets.

key_stories.title: Load-time push: faster decompression vs side-effects of rendering optimizations
key_stories.summary: Kaze times a roughly three-second load and calls it unacceptable, then considers integrating a faster decompression algorithm suggested by EggLab. He also notices emulator discrepancies and suspects some rendering optimizations may have worsened loading, turning performance work into a multi-variable investigation.
key_stories.challenge: Level load times feel too long, and performance is inconsistent across emulators/testing contexts.
key_stories.process: He benchmarks load time, compares emulator behavior, and explores swapping in a faster decompressor while questioning earlier graphics pipeline changes.
key_stories.outcome: A promising technical lead (2x decompression) is identified, but integration and root-cause analysis remain pending.
key_stories.key_quote: Three seconds of load time, which I think is a little unacceptable.

key_stories.title: Cloud Cap stage crash triggers pipeline concern
key_stories.summary: While setting up exits/warps and moving toward the next development chunk, Kaze experiences a crash when opening the Cloud Cap stage. Even with Git backups available, he treats the crash as a serious reliability issue to diagnose rather than simply reverting.
key_stories.challenge: A key level (Cloud Cap stage) crashes on open, threatening iteration speed and possibly risking data integrity.
key_stories.process: He acknowledges the crash, notes backups exist, and states a preference to identify the failure cause.
key_stories.outcome: He postpones further work until next stream and flags investigating the crash as a priority.
key_stories.key_quote: That's concerning... I'd rather find out why it's not working.

open_questions.topic: ROM space recovery and asset deletion criteria
open_questions.context: Kaze deletes unused vanilla SM64 assets and gains ~0.5MB, implying he has a methodology for determining what can be safely removed.
questions: What exact asset categories did you remove (textures, animations, level geometry, audio banks), and how did you verify nothing still referenced them?
Was this cleanup prompted by a near-miss (running out of space), or was it proactive engineering hygiene?
Did freeing ROM space also affect RAM usage or build complexity, or was it purely ROM footprint?

open_questions.context: EggLab’s decompressor is presented as ~2x faster and targeted at reducing unacceptable load times.
questions: What compression format is RTYI currently using (and where in the pipeline is decompression happening: boot, level load, segmented assets)?
What are the trade-offs of EggLab’s approach (ROM size increase, RAM usage, CPU spikes, compatibility with hardware/everdrive, determinism)?
How will you validate real-hardware improvements versus emulator-only gains?

open_questions.topic: Performance regression risk from graphics/render optimizations
open_questions.context: Kaze suspects his rendering optimizations may have slowed loading, suggesting competing performance objectives (frame-time vs load-time).
questions: Which specific graphics optimizations affected loading (display list rebuilds, segment uploads, texture streaming, RSP/RDP workload)?
Do you have a profiling workflow on real N64 to separate load-time CPU cost from render-time cost?
How do you decide when to accept a load-time hit in exchange for in-level performance/visuals?

open_questions.topic: Course 2 beta-test process and iteration loop
open_questions.context: Kaze references many beta tests and watching beta videos, with targeted changes that reduce annoyance and improve readability underwater.
questions: Who are the beta testers and how are they recruited/organized (private group, community members, team)?
What feedback format is most useful to you (raw footage, written notes, heatmaps, completion times), and why?
Which single Course 2 change had the biggest impact on player comprehension or frustration?

open_questions.topic: Cloud Cap stage crash root cause
open_questions.context: Opening the Cloud Cap stage crashes, and Kaze wants diagnosis rather than just restoring from backup.
questions: What exactly crashes (editor tool, build process, emulator, the game on boot), and what error signals do you get?
Did this start after a specific commit (engine rework, asset import, warp/exit setup), and can you bisect to isolate it?
Is this crash symptomatic of a broader data/format fragility that could affect other levels late in development?
